Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: configuration
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: The service configuration used to instantiate this service client.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: +defaultTranslate
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Returns the singleton service client. If the singleton object does not exist, the SDK instantiates the default service client with defaultServiceConfiguration from [AWSServiceManager defaultServiceManager]. The reference to this object is maintained by the SDK, and you do not need to retain it manually.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: +registerTranslateWithConfiguration:forKey:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Creates a service client with the given service configuration and registers it for the key.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: +TranslateForKey:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Retrieves the service client associated with the key. You need to call + registerTranslateWithConfiguration:forKey: before invoking this method.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: +removeTranslateForKey:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Removes the service client associated with the key and release it.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -createParallelData:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Creates a parallel data resource in Amazon Translate by importing an input file from Amazon S3. Parallel data files contain examples that show how you want segments of text to be translated. By adding parallel data, you can influence the style, tone, and word choice in your translation output.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -createParallelData:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Creates a parallel data resource in Amazon Translate by importing an input file from Amazon S3. Parallel data files contain examples that show how you want segments of text to be translated. By adding parallel data, you can influence the style, tone, and word choice in your translation output.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -deleteParallelData:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Deletes a parallel data resource in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -deleteParallelData:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Deletes a parallel data resource in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -deleteTerminology:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: A synchronous action that deletes a custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -deleteTerminology:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: A synchronous action that deletes a custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -describeTextTranslationJob:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Gets the properties associated with an asynchronous batch translation job including name, ID, status, source and target languages, input/output S3 buckets, and so on.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -describeTextTranslationJob:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Gets the properties associated with an asynchronous batch translation job including name, ID, status, source and target languages, input/output S3 buckets, and so on.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -getParallelData:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides information about a parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -getParallelData:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides information about a parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -getTerminology:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Retrieves a custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -getTerminology:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Retrieves a custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -importTerminology:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Creates or updates a custom terminology, depending on whether or not one already exists for the given terminology name. Importing a terminology with the same name as an existing one will merge the terminologies based on the chosen merge strategy. Currently, the only supported merge strategy is OVERWRITE, and so the imported terminology will overwrite an existing terminology of the same name.

If you import a terminology that overwrites an existing one, the new terminology take up to 10 minutes to fully propagate and be available for use in a translation due to cache policies with the DataPlane service that performs the translations.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -importTerminology:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Creates or updates a custom terminology, depending on whether or not one already exists for the given terminology name. Importing a terminology with the same name as an existing one will merge the terminologies based on the chosen merge strategy. Currently, the only supported merge strategy is OVERWRITE, and so the imported terminology will overwrite an existing terminology of the same name.

If you import a terminology that overwrites an existing one, the new terminology take up to 10 minutes to fully propagate and be available for use in a translation due to cache policies with the DataPlane service that performs the translations.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listParallelData:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides a list of your parallel data resources in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listParallelData:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides a list of your parallel data resources in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listTerminologies:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides a list of custom terminologies associated with your account.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listTerminologies:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Provides a list of custom terminologies associated with your account.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listTextTranslationJobs:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Gets a list of the batch translation jobs that you have submitted.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -listTextTranslationJobs:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Gets a list of the batch translation jobs that you have submitted.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -startTextTranslationJob:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Starts an asynchronous batch translation job. Batch translation jobs can be used to translate large volumes of text across multiple documents at once. For more information, see async.

Batch translation jobs can be described with the DescribeTextTranslationJob operation, listed with the ListTextTranslationJobs operation, and stopped with the StopTextTranslationJob operation.

Amazon Translate does not support batch translation of multiple source languages at once.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -startTextTranslationJob:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Starts an asynchronous batch translation job. Batch translation jobs can be used to translate large volumes of text across multiple documents at once. For more information, see async.

Batch translation jobs can be described with the DescribeTextTranslationJob operation, listed with the ListTextTranslationJobs operation, and stopped with the StopTextTranslationJob operation.

Amazon Translate does not support batch translation of multiple source languages at once.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -stopTextTranslationJob:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Stops an asynchronous batch translation job that is in progress.

If the job’s state is IN_PROGRESS, the job will be marked for termination and put into the STOP_REQUESTED state. If the job completes before it can be stopped, it is put into the COMPLETED state. Otherwise, the job is put into the STOPPED state.

Asynchronous batch translation jobs are started with the StartTextTranslationJob operation. You can use the DescribeTextTranslationJob or ListTextTranslationJobs operations to get a batch translation job’s JobId.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -stopTextTranslationJob:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract:
Stops an asynchronous batch translation job that is in progress.

If the job’s state is IN_PROGRESS, the job will be marked for termination and put into the STOP_REQUESTED state. If the job completes before it can be stopped, it is put into the COMPLETED state. Otherwise, the job is put into the STOPPED state.

Asynchronous batch translation jobs are started with the StartTextTranslationJob operation. You can use the DescribeTextTranslationJob or ListTextTranslationJobs operations to get a batch translation job’s JobId.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -translateText:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Translates input text from the source language to the target language. For a list of available languages and language codes, see what-is-languages.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -translateText:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Translates input text from the source language to the target language. For a list of available languages and language codes, see what-is-languages.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -updateParallelData:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Updates a previously created parallel data resource by importing a new input file from Amazon S3.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: -updateParallelData:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSTranslate.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Updates a previously created parallel data resource by importing a new input file from Amazon S3.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: latestUpdateAttemptAt
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: The time that the most recent update was attempted.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: latestUpdateAttemptStatus
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: The status of the parallel data update attempt. When the updated parallel data resource is ready for you to use, the status is ACTIVE.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: The name of the parallel data resource being updated.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: status
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: The status of the parallel data resource that you are attempting to update. Your update request is accepted only if this status is either ACTIVE or FAILED.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: clientToken
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: A unique identifier for the request. This token is automatically generated when you use Amazon Translate through an AWS SDK.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: detail
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: A custom description for the parallel data resource in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: The name of the parallel data resource being updated.

Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.name: parallelDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateUpdateParallelDataRe.abstract: Specifies the format and S3 location of the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslationSettings..name: profanity
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslationSettings..abstract:
Enable the profanity setting if you want Amazon Translate to mask profane words and phrases in your translation output.

To mask profane words and phrases, Amazon Translate replaces them with the grawlix string “?$#@$“. This 5-character sequence is used for each profane word or phrase, regardless of the length or number of words.

Amazon Translate does not detect profanity in all of its supported languages. For languages that support profanity detection, see Supported Languages and Language Codes in the Amazon Translate Developer Guide.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.name: appliedTerminologies
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.abstract: The names of the custom terminologies applied to the input text by Amazon Translate for the translated text response.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.abstract: The language code for the language of the source text.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.name: targetLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRespons.abstract: The language code for the language of the target text.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.name: settings
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.abstract: Settings to configure your translation output, including the option to mask profane words and phrases.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.abstract:
The language code for the language of the source text. The language must be a language supported by Amazon Translate. For a list of language codes, see what-is-languages.

To have Amazon Translate determine the source language of your text, you can specify auto in the SourceLanguageCode field. If you specify auto, Amazon Translate will call Amazon Comprehend to determine the source language.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.name: targetLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.abstract: The language code requested for the language of the target text. The language must be a language supported by Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.name: terminologyNames
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.abstract: The name of the terminology list file to be used in the TranslateText request. You can use 1 terminology list at most in a TranslateText request. Terminology lists can contain a maximum of 256 terms.

Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.name: text
Classes/AWSTranslateTranslateTextRequest.abstract: The text to translate. The text string can be a maximum of 5,000 bytes long. Depending on your character set, this may be fewer than 5,000 characters.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: dataAccessRoleArn
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AWS Identity Access and Management (IAM) role that granted Amazon Translate read access to the job’s input data.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: endTime
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The time at which the translation job ended.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: inputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The input configuration properties that were specified when the job was requested.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: jobDetails
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The number of documents successfully and unsuccessfully processed during the translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: jobName
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The user-defined name of the translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: message
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: An explanation of any errors that may have occurred during the translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: outputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The output configuration properties that were specified when the job was requested.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: parallelDataNames
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: A list containing the names of the parallel data resources applied to the translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The language code of the language of the source text. The language must be a language supported by Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: submittedTime
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The time at which the translation job was submitted.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: targetLanguageCodes
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: The language code of the language of the target text. The language must be a language supported by Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.name: terminologyNames
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobPr.abstract: A list containing the names of the terminologies applied to a translation job. Only one terminology can be applied per StartTextTranslationJob request at this time.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.name: jobName
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.abstract: Filters the list of jobs by name.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.name: jobStatus
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.abstract: Filters the list of jobs based by job status.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.name: submittedAfterTime
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.abstract: Filters the list of jobs based on the time that the job was submitted for processing and returns only the jobs submitted after the specified time. Jobs are returned in descending order, newest to oldest.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.name: submittedBeforeTime
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.abstract: Filters the list of jobs based on the time that the job was submitted for processing and returns only the jobs submitted before the specified time. Jobs are returned in ascending order, oldest to newest.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: arn
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: createdAt
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The time at which the custom terminology was created, based on the timestamp.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: detail
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The description of the custom terminology properties.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: directionality
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract:
The directionality of your terminology resource indicates whether it has one source language (uni-directional) or multiple (multi-directional).

UNI

The terminology resource has one source language (the first column in a CSV file), and all of its other languages are target languages.

MULTI

Any language in the terminology resource can be the source language.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: encryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The encryption key for the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: format
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The format of the custom terminology input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: lastUpdatedAt
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The time at which the custom terminology was last update, based on the timestamp.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: message
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: Additional information from Amazon Translate about the terminology resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: sizeBytes
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The size of the file used when importing a custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: skippedTermCount
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The number of terms in the input file that Amazon Translate skipped when you created or updated the terminology resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The language code for the source text of the translation request for which the custom terminology is being used.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: targetLanguageCodes
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The language codes for the target languages available with the custom terminology resource. All possible target languages are returned in array.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.name: termCount
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyPropertie.abstract: The number of terms included in the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.name: location
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.abstract:
The Amazon S3 location of the most recent custom terminology input file that was successfully imported into Amazon Translate. The location is returned as a presigned URL that has a 30 minute expiration.

Amazon Translate doesn’t scan all input files for the risk of CSV injection attacks.

CSV injection occurs when a .csv or .tsv file is altered so that a record contains malicious code. The record begins with a special character, such as =, +, -, or @. When the file is opened in a spreadsheet program, the program might interpret the record as a formula and run the code within it.

Before you download an input file from Amazon S3, ensure that you recognize the file and trust its creator.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.name: repositoryType
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.abstract: The repository type for the custom terminology data.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.name: directionality
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.abstract:
The directionality of your terminology resource indicates whether it has one source language (uni-directional) or multiple (multi-directional).

UNI

The terminology resource has one source language (for example, the first column in a CSV file), and all of its other languages are target languages.

MULTI

Any language in the terminology resource can be the source language or a target language. A single multi-directional terminology resource can be used for jobs that translate different language pairs. For example, if the terminology contains terms in English and Spanish, then it can be used for jobs that translate English to Spanish and jobs that translate Spanish to English.

When you create a custom terminology resource without specifying the directionality, it behaves as uni-directional terminology, although this parameter will have a null value.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.name: file
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.abstract: The file containing the custom terminology data. Your version of the AWS SDK performs a Base64-encoding on this field before sending a request to the AWS service. Users of the SDK should not perform Base64-encoding themselves.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.name: format
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.abstract: The data format of the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html#/c:objc(cs.name: sourceText
Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html#/c:objc(cs.abstract: The source text of the term being translated by the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html#/c:objc(cs.name: targetText
Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html#/c:objc(cs.abstract: The target text of the term being translated by the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.name: jobId
Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.abstract: The job ID of the stopped batch translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.name: jobStatus
Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.abstract: The status of the designated job. Upon successful completion, the job’s status will be STOPPED.

Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.name: jobId
Classes/AWSTranslateStopTextTranslationJ.abstract: The job ID of the job to be stopped.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: jobId
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: The identifier generated for the job. To get the status of a job, use this ID with the DescribeTextTranslationJob operation.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: jobStatus
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract:
The status of the job. Possible values include:

  • SUBMITTED - The job has been received and is queued for processing.

  • IN_PROGRESS - Amazon Translate is processing the job.

  • COMPLETED - The job was successfully completed and the output is available.

  • COMPLETED_WITH_ERROR - The job was completed with errors. The errors can be analyzed in the job’s output.

  • FAILED - The job did not complete. To get details, use the DescribeTextTranslationJob operation.

  • STOP_REQUESTED - The user who started the job has requested that it be stopped.

  • STOPPED - The job has been stopped.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: clientToken
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: A unique identifier for the request. This token is auto-generated when using the Amazon Translate SDK.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: dataAccessRoleArn
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AWS Identity Access and Management (IAM) role that grants Amazon Translate read access to your input data. For more information, see identity-and-access-management.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: inputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: Specifies the format and S3 location of the input documents for the translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: jobName
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: The name of the batch translation job to be performed.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: outputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: Specifies the S3 folder to which your job output will be saved.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: parallelDataNames
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract:
The name of a parallel data resource to add to the translation job. This resource consists of examples that show how you want segments of text to be translated. When you add parallel data to a translation job, you create an Active Custom Translation job.

This parameter accepts only one parallel data resource.

Active Custom Translation jobs are priced at a higher rate than other jobs that don’t use parallel data. For more information, see Amazon Translate pricing.

For a list of available parallel data resources, use the ListParallelData operation.

For more information, see customizing-translations-parallel-data.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: settings
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: Settings to configure your translation output, including the option to mask profane words and phrases.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract:
The language code of the input language. For a list of language codes, see what-is-languages.

Amazon Translate does not automatically detect a source language during batch translation jobs.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: targetLanguageCodes
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract: The language code of the output language.

Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.name: terminologyNames
Classes/AWSTranslateStartTextTranslation.abstract:
The name of a custom terminology resource to add to the translation job. This resource lists examples source terms and the desired translation for each term.

This parameter accepts only one custom terminology resource.

For a list of available custom terminology resources, use the ListTerminologies operation.

For more information, see how-custom-terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: arn
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: createdAt
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The time at which the parallel data resource was created.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: detail
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The description assigned to the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: encryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The encryption key used to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: failedRecordCount
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The number of records unsuccessfully imported from the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: importedDataSize
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The number of UTF-8 characters that Amazon Translate imported from the parallel data input file. This number includes only the characters in your translation examples. It does not include characters that are used to format your file. For example, if you provided a Translation Memory Exchange (.tmx) file, this number does not include the tags.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: importedRecordCount
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The number of records successfully imported from the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: lastUpdatedAt
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The time at which the parallel data resource was last updated.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: latestUpdateAttemptAt
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The time that the most recent update was attempted.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: latestUpdateAttemptStatus
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The status of the most recent update attempt for the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: message
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: Additional information from Amazon Translate about the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The custom name assigned to the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: parallelDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: Specifies the format and S3 location of the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: skippedRecordCount
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The number of items in the input file that Amazon Translate skipped when you created or updated the parallel data resource. For example, Amazon Translate skips empty records, empty target texts, and empty lines.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: sourceLanguageCode
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The source language of the translations in the parallel data file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: status
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The status of the parallel data resource. When the parallel data is ready for you to use, the status is ACTIVE.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: targetLanguageCodes
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The language codes for the target languages available in the parallel data file. All possible target languages are returned as an array.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.name: location
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.abstract:
The Amazon S3 location of the parallel data input file. The location is returned as a presigned URL to that has a 30 minute expiration.

Amazon Translate doesn’t scan all input files for the risk of CSV injection attacks.

CSV injection occurs when a .csv or .tsv file is altered so that a record contains malicious code. The record begins with a special character, such as =, +, -, or @. When the file is opened in a spreadsheet program, the program might interpret the record as a formula and run the code within it.

Before you download an input file from Amazon S3, ensure that you recognize the file and trust its creator.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.name: repositoryType
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.abstract: Describes the repository that contains the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.name: format
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.abstract: The format of the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.name: s3Uri
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.abstract: The URI of the Amazon S3 folder that contains the parallel data input file. The folder must be in the same Region as the API endpoint you are calling.

Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.name: encryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.abstract: The encryption key used to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.name: s3Uri
Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.abstract: The URI of the S3 folder that contains a translation job’s output file. The folder must be in the same Region as the API endpoint that you are calling.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.abstract: The token to use to retrieve the next page of results. This value is null when there are no more results to return.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.name: textTranslationJobPropertiesList
Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.abstract: A list containing the properties of each job that is returned.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.name: filter
Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.abstract: The parameters that specify which batch translation jobs to retrieve. Filters include job name, job status, and submission time. You can only set one filter at a time.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.name: maxResults
Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.abstract: The maximum number of results to return in each page. The default value is 100.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListTextTranslationJ.abstract: The token to request the next page of results.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesRes.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesRes.abstract: If the response to the ListTerminologies was truncated, the NextToken fetches the next group of custom terminologies.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesRes.name: terminologyPropertiesList
Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesRes.abstract: The properties list of the custom terminologies returned on the list request.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesReq.name: maxResults
Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesReq.abstract: The maximum number of custom terminologies returned per list request.

Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesReq.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListTerminologiesReq.abstract: If the result of the request to ListTerminologies was truncated, include the NextToken to fetch the next group of custom terminologies.

Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataResp.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataResp.abstract: The string to use in a subsequent request to get the next page of results in a paginated response. This value is null if there are no additional pages.

Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataResp.name: parallelDataPropertiesList
Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataResp.abstract: The properties of the parallel data resources returned by this request.

Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataRequ.name: maxResults
Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataRequ.abstract: The maximum number of parallel data resources returned for each request.

Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataRequ.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSTranslateListParallelDataRequ.abstract: A string that specifies the next page of results to return in a paginated response.

Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.name: documentsWithErrorsCount
Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.abstract: The number of documents that could not be processed during a translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.name: inputDocumentsCount
Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.abstract: The number of documents used as input in a translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.name: translatedDocumentsCount
Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html#/c:o.abstract: The number of documents successfully processed during a translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.name: contentType
Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.abstract:
Describes the format of the data that you submit to Amazon Translate as input. You can specify one of the following multipurpose internet mail extension (MIME) types:

  • text/html: The input data consists of one or more HTML files. Amazon Translate translates only the text that resides in the html element in each file.

  • text/plain: The input data consists of one or more unformatted text files. Amazon Translate translates every character in this type of input.

  • application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document: The input data consists of one or more Word documents (.docx).

  • application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.presentationml.presentation: The input data consists of one or more PowerPoint Presentation files (.pptx).

  • application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet: The input data consists of one or more Excel Workbook files (.xlsx).

  • application/x-xliff+xml: The input data consists of one or more XML Localization Interchange File Format (XLIFF) files (.xlf). Amazon Translate supports only XLIFF version 1.2.

If you structure your input data as HTML, ensure that you set this parameter to text/html. By doing so, you cut costs by limiting the translation to the contents of the html element in each file. Otherwise, if you set this parameter to text/plain, your costs will cover the translation of every character.

Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.name: s3Uri
Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.abstract: The URI of the AWS S3 folder that contains the input file. The folder must be in the same Region as the API endpoint you are calling.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyRes.name: auxiliaryDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyRes.abstract: The Amazon S3 location of a file that provides any errors or warnings that were produced by your input file. This file was created when Amazon Translate attempted to create a terminology resource. The location is returned as a presigned URL to that has a 30 minute expiration.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyRes.name: terminologyProperties
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyRes.abstract: The properties of the custom terminology being imported.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.name: detail
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.abstract: The description of the custom terminology being imported.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.name: encryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.abstract: The encryption key for the custom terminology being imported.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.name: mergeStrategy
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.abstract: The merge strategy of the custom terminology being imported. Currently, only the OVERWRITE merge strategy is supported. In this case, the imported terminology will overwrite an existing terminology of the same name.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.abstract: The name of the custom terminology being imported.

Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.name: terminologyData
Classes/AWSTranslateImportTerminologyReq.abstract: The terminology data for the custom terminology being imported.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.name: auxiliaryDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.abstract: The Amazon S3 location of a file that provides any errors or warnings that were produced by your input file. This file was created when Amazon Translate attempted to create a terminology resource. The location is returned as a presigned URL to that has a 30 minute expiration.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.name: terminologyDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.abstract:
The Amazon S3 location of the most recent custom terminology input file that was successfully imported into Amazon Translate. The location is returned as a presigned URL that has a 30 minute expiration.

Amazon Translate doesn’t scan all input files for the risk of CSV injection attacks.

CSV injection occurs when a .csv or .tsv file is altered so that a record contains malicious code. The record begins with a special character, such as =, +, -, or @. When the file is opened in a spreadsheet program, the program might interpret the record as a formula and run the code within it.

Before you download an input file from Amazon S3, ensure that you recognize the file and trust its creator.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.name: terminologyProperties
Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyRespon.abstract: The properties of the custom terminology being retrieved.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyReques.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyReques.abstract: The name of the custom terminology being retrieved.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyReques.name: terminologyDataFormat
Classes/AWSTranslateGetTerminologyReques.abstract:
The data format of the custom terminology being retrieved.

If you don’t specify this parameter, Amazon Translate returns a file that has the same format as the file that was imported to create the terminology.

If you specify this parameter when you retrieve a multi-directional terminology resource, you must specify the same format as that of the input file that was imported to create it. Otherwise, Amazon Translate throws an error.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.name: auxiliaryDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.abstract: The Amazon S3 location of a file that provides any errors or warnings that were produced by your input file. This file was created when Amazon Translate attempted to create a parallel data resource. The location is returned as a presigned URL to that has a 30 minute expiration.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.name: dataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.abstract:
The Amazon S3 location of the most recent parallel data input file that was successfully imported into Amazon Translate. The location is returned as a presigned URL that has a 30 minute expiration.

Amazon Translate doesn’t scan all input files for the risk of CSV injection attacks.

CSV injection occurs when a .csv or .tsv file is altered so that a record contains malicious code. The record begins with a special character, such as =, +, -, or @. When the file is opened in a spreadsheet program, the program might interpret the record as a formula and run the code within it.

Before you download an input file from Amazon S3, ensure that you recognize the file and trust its creator.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.name: latestUpdateAttemptAuxiliaryDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.abstract: The Amazon S3 location of a file that provides any errors or warnings that were produced by your input file. This file was created when Amazon Translate attempted to update a parallel data resource. The location is returned as a presigned URL to that has a 30 minute expiration.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.name: parallelDataProperties
Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataRespo.abstract: The properties of the parallel data resource that is being retrieved.

Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataReque.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateGetParallelDataReque.abstract: The name of the parallel data resource that is being retrieved.

Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html#/.name: identifier
Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html#/.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the encryption key being used to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html#/.name: types
Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html#/.abstract: The type of encryption key used by Amazon Translate to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateDescribeTextTranslat.name: textTranslationJobProperties
Classes/AWSTranslateDescribeTextTranslat.abstract: An object that contains the properties associated with an asynchronous batch translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateDescribeTextTranslat.name: jobId
Classes/AWSTranslateDescribeTextTranslat.abstract: The identifier that Amazon Translate generated for the job. The StartTextTranslationJob operation returns this identifier in its response.

Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteTerminologyReq.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteTerminologyReq.abstract: The name of the custom terminology being deleted.

Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.abstract: The name of the parallel data resource that is being deleted.

Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.name: status
Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.abstract: The status of the parallel data deletion.

Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateDeleteParallelDataRe.abstract: The name of the parallel data resource that is being deleted.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: The custom name that you assigned to the parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: status
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: The status of the parallel data resource. When the resource is ready for you to use, the status is ACTIVE.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: clientToken
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: A unique identifier for the request. This token is automatically generated when you use Amazon Translate through an AWS SDK.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: detail
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: A custom description for the parallel data resource in Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: encryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: The encryption key used to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: A custom name for the parallel data resource in Amazon Translate. You must assign a name that is unique in the account and region.

Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.name: parallelDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateCreateParallelDataRe.abstract: Specifies the format and S3 location of the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.name: name
Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.abstract: The name of the custom terminology applied to the input text by Amazon Translate for the translated text response.

Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.name: terms
Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.abstract: The specific terms of the custom terminology applied to the input text by Amazon Translate for the translated text response. A maximum of 250 terms will be returned, and the specific terms applied will be the first 250 terms in the source text.

Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.name: AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology
Classes/AWSTranslateAppliedTerminology.h.abstract: The custom terminology applied to the input text by Amazon Translate for the translated text response. This is optional in the response and will only be present if you specified terminology input in the request. Currently, only one terminology can be applied per TranslateText request.

Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html.name: AWSTranslateEncryptionKey
Classes/AWSTranslateEncryptionKey.html.abstract: The encryption key used to encrypt this object.

Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.name: AWSTranslateInputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateInputDataConfig.html.abstract: The input configuration properties for requesting a batch translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html.name: AWSTranslateJobDetails
Classes/AWSTranslateJobDetails.html.abstract: The number of documents successfully and unsuccessfully processed during a translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.name: AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateOutputDataConfig.htm.abstract: The output configuration properties for a batch translation job.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.name: AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataConfig.h.abstract: Specifies the format and S3 location of the parallel data input file.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.name: AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataDataLoca.abstract: The location of the most recent parallel data input file that was successfully imported into Amazon Translate.

Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.name: AWSTranslateParallelDataProperties
Classes/AWSTranslateParallelDataProperti.abstract: The properties of a parallel data resource.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html.name: AWSTranslateTerm
Classes/AWSTranslateTerm.html.abstract: The term being translated by the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.name: AWSTranslateTerminologyData
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyData.html.abstract: The data associated with the custom terminology.

Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.name: AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocation
Classes/AWSTranslateTerminologyDataLocat.abstract: The location of the custom terminology data.

Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.name: AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFilter
Classes/AWSTranslateTextTranslationJobFi.abstract: Provides information for filtering a list of translation jobs. For more information, see ListTextTranslationJobs.

Classes/AWSTranslate.html.name: AWSTranslate
Classes/AWSTranslate.html.abstract: Provides translation between one source language and another of the same set of languages.
